Efforts are on to CREATE AWARENESS about it

It could be a worker from a foundry, textile mill, processing unit, an employee of an IT company or a bank – there is an increasing effort and need to create awareness about work-related health problems.

The Department of Industrial Health and Safety organises meetings at two factories in each division every month to create awareness on occupational health, diseases, and sanitation.

Workers can also complain to the department if the facilities available to ensure a healthy environment are not available.

Workers too need to discuss often about their health and adopt a lifestyle that will keep them healthy. They need to tell doctors about their occupation when they take treatment for an ailment, says K. Arul, additional chief inspector of factories.

Several manufacturing units, including those that employ north Indian workers, now have facilities for the workers to play outdoor games, come up with balanced and healthy diet at the in-house canteens, organise health camps and encourage the workers to be more health conscious.

Diabetologist V. Rajendran of Dr. Rajendran’s Diabetes Centre says youngsters in professions that have a sedentary lifestyle (such as Information Technology) are more prone to problems such as diabetes.

With pressure and stress to go up the ladder at work, they have the risk of diabetes, especially if there is a family history of diabetes.

Diet, lifestyle and exercise are important and doctors also ask the patients about their family and occupation.

Awareness is improving among those who are diabetic.

But, among the general public, it is more of “not me” attitude and this has to change, he says.

M. Soundariya Preetha
title: Occupational health problems
